paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b, an Earth-sized rocky planet orbiting an M dwarf on a short tidally locked orbit, retain any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed System
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: one rocky exoplanet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: TRAPPIST-1 b, an Earth-sized rocky exoplanet observed with JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve to measure thermal phase variation and spectral structure.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Null Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution serving as the null scenario to compare against atmosphere-bearing interpretations.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-Rich Atmosphere
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmosphere model with significant CO2 greenhouse gas absorption, testing whether such an atmosphere could explain the observed phase-curve and spectral data.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-Rich Atmosphere
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An oxidized composition scenario with weaker CO2 signature constraints, representing an alternative atmospheric interpretation.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions including circulation, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
